main event: On 30th March 1950, an unidentified flying object was observed near Greater Pittsburgh Airport. The object was described as a 50 ft diameter, white, round object that climbed from an estimated altitude of 2,000-2,500 ft to 20,000 ft in 5 minutes before disappearing to the east at a speed of 50-60 mph.
interesting points: The object emitted no sound and no trail, but it had what appeared to be an exhaust flame in the center.
The sighting was made by Ist Lt James A. Frazier and Paul Raymon, both members of the 2239th AFRTC, providing military credibility to the observation.
The object was observed for approximately five minutes and appeared to hover before climbing out of sight, displaying unusual behavior for any known aircraft at the time.
Despite the detailed observation, no photographs or sketches of the object were made, adding to the mystery of the sighting.
The object's appearance and behavior did not match known aircraft or natural phenomena, leading to its classification as an unidentified flying object.
witnesses: Military personnel - Ist Lt James A. Frazier and Paul Raymon
